  14. (**************************************************************************)

  16. (** Locks for mutual exclusion.

  18.    Mutexes (mutual-exclusion locks) are used to implement critical sections
  19.    and protect shared mutable data structures against concurrent accesses.
  20.    The typical use is (if [m] is the mutex associated with the data structure
  21.    [D]):
  22.    {[
  23.      Mutex.lock m;
  24.      (* Critical section that operates over D *);
  25.      Mutex.unlock m
  26.    ]}
  27. *)

  29. ‌type t
  30. (** The type of mutexes. *)

  32. ‌val create : unit -> t
  33. (** Return a new mutex. *)

  35. ‌val lock : t -> unit
  36. (** Lock the given mutex. Only one thread can have the mutex locked
  37.    at any time. A thread that attempts to lock a mutex already locked
  38.    by another thread will suspend until the other thread unlocks
  39.    the mutex.

  41.    @raise Sys_error if the mutex is already locked by the thread calling
  42.    {!Mutex.lock}.

  44.    @before 4.12 {!Sys_error} was not raised for recursive locking
  45.    (platform-dependent behaviour) *)

  47. ‌val try_lock : t -> bool
  48. (** Same as {!Mutex.lock}, but does not suspend the calling thread if
  49.    the mutex is already locked: just return [false] immediately
  50.    in that case. If the mutex is unlocked, lock it and
  51.    return [true]. *)

  53. ‌val unlock : t -> unit
  54. (** Unlock the given mutex. Other threads suspended trying to lock
  55.    the mutex will restart.  The mutex must have been previously locked
  56.    by the thread that calls {!Mutex.unlock}.
  57.    @raise Sys_error if the mutex is unlocked or was locked by another thread.

  59.    @before 4.12 {!Sys_error} was not raised when unlocking an unlocked mutex
  60.    or when unlocking a mutex from a different thread. *)

  62. ‌val protect : t -> (unit -> 'a) -> 'a
  63. (** [protect mutex f] runs [f()] in a critical section where [mutex]
  64.     is locked (using {!lock}); it then takes care of releasing [mutex],
  65.     whether [f()] returned a value or raised an exception.

  67.     The unlocking operation is guaranteed to always takes place,
  68.     even in the event an asynchronous exception (e.g. {!Sys.Break}) is raised
  69.     in some signal handler.

  71.     @since 5.1 *)
